title: Judgment on the Philistines
shortSummary: Jeremiah 47 delivers a prophetic oracle against the Philistines, foretelling their destruction by an overwhelming force from the north. This chapter emphasizes God's sovereign judgment on nations opposing His people and highlights the certainty of divine punishment for sin.
timeline: c. 627-586 BC - Late 7th to early 6th century BC, during Jeremiah's prophetic ministry before the Babylonian exile

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who receives and delivers God's message of judgment against the Philistines.

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh
keyCharacters.description: The Egyptian ruler mentioned as having smitten Gaza, providing historical context for the prophecy.

keyCharacters.name: Philistines
keyCharacters.description: The people and nation targeted by God's judgment through Jeremiah's prophecy.

outline.heading: Introduction and Context of the Prophecy
outline.description: The chapter opens by identifying the prophecy as a word from the LORD against the Philistines, given before Pharaoh's attack on Gaza, setting the historical and prophetic context.

outline.heading: The Coming Judgment Described
outline.description: God declares an overwhelming flood from the north that will devastate the land and its inhabitants, symbolizing the invading army that will bring ruin to the Philistines and their allies.

outline.heading: The Effects of Judgment on Philistine Cities
outline.description: The prophecy details the desolation of key Philistine cities like Gaza and Ashkelon, highlighting the severity and personal anguish of the coming judgment.

outline.heading: The Sword of the LORD and Its Divine Charge
outline.description: The sword, representing God's instrument of judgment, is personified and questioned about resting, but it cannot cease because God has commanded it to execute judgment on Ashkelon and the coastal region.

application: Trust in God's sovereignty over nations and recognize that He executes justice according to His perfect will.
Respond to God's warnings with repentance, understanding that judgment is certain for persistent rebellion.
Pray for God's mercy on those who oppose His people and for the fulfillment of His righteous purposes.

keyVerses.text: Thus saith the LORD; Behold, waters rise up out of the north, and shall be an overflowing flood, and shall overflow the land, and all that is therein; the city, and them that dwell therein: then the men shall cry, and all the inhabitants of the land shall howl.
keyVerses.significance: This verse vividly portrays the unstoppable judgment of God as an overwhelming flood, emphasizing the certainty and totality of His wrath against sin.

keyVerses.text: Because of the day that cometh to spoil all the Philistines, and to cut off from Tyrus and Zidon every helper that remaineth: for the LORD will spoil the Philistines, the remnant of the country of Caphtor.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights God's sovereign power to bring down even the allies of the Philistines, underscoring that no help can withstand His judgment.

keyVerses.text: O thou sword of the LORD, how long will it be ere thou be quiet? put up thyself into thy scabbard, rest, and be still.
keyVerses.significance: This verse personifies God's instrument of judgment, illustrating the tension between divine justice and the desire for peace, yet affirming that God's purposes must be fulfilled.
